1.question:
1 (a) Solve:

   (i)  2x = 18  
   (ii) x + 2 = 5  
   (iii) x/3 = 15  

(b)  
   (i) Find the value of t when g = 4 and h = 7.  
       t = 12g − 5h  
   (ii) Rearrange 4r − p = q to make r the subject.

question-components.b.i: Find the value of t when g = 4 and h = 7. t = 12g − 5h
question-components.b.ii: Rearrange 4r − p = q to make r the subject.

2.question:
2   Cambury Council asked 60 customers what they thought of the local leisure centre.  
The results are shown in this bar chart:

• Excellent: 15  
• Good: 30  
• Could be improved: 10  
• Not good enough: 5  

Draw and label a pie chart to represent this data.  

[5]
2.question-components: Draw and label a pie chart to represent this data.

question-components.a: How many 20p coins would you need to make up £7000?
question-components.b: Each 20p coin weighs 5 g. Lizzie says: “I can lift £7000 worth of 20p coins.” Is Lizzie’s claim reasonable? Show your working and state any assumptions you have made.
question-components.c: How have any assumptions you have made affected your answer to part (b)?

4.question:
4 Antonio works Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.  
He starts work at 4.00 pm and finishes at 10.30 pm.  
Antonio is paid £10 per hour on weekdays.  

One week, he also works for 4 hours on Sunday.  
He is paid 50% more on Sundays.  

How much does Antonio earn altogether this week?  
You must show your working.  

£ ..................................................... [6]
4.question-components: How much does Antonio earn altogether this week? You must show your working.

5.question-components: Darren says: “I can run 100 m in 15 seconds, so I should be able to run 800 m in 120 seconds.” Do you think that he would take more or less than 120 seconds to run 800 m? Explain your answer, with reference to any assumptions Darren has made.

6.question:
6  Jo makes a pendant from a rectangular piece of silver.

 ┌─────────┐
 │         │  8 cm
 │         │
 └─────────┘
      5 cm

(a) Work out the area of this rectangle.  
(a) …………………… cm²  [1]

(b) To complete the pendant, Jo cuts two semicircles of radius 1 cm from the rectangle, as shown below.

 ┌─────────┐
 │   ___   │  8 cm
 │  (   )  │
 │   ‾‾‾   │
 └─────────┘
      5 cm

Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.  [4]

(c) The silver Jo uses is 2 mm thick.  
Find the volume of silver in the pendant.  
Give your answer in cm³.

(c) …………………… cm³  [3]

question-components.a: Work out the area of this rectangle.
question-components.b: Show that the shaded area is 36.9 cm² correct to three significant figures.
question-components.c: Find the volume of silver in the pendant. Give your answer in cm³.

7.question:
7  PQRS is a rectangle.  
   A, B, C and D are points on SP, PQ, QR and RS respectively.  
   AC is the line of symmetry for the diagram.  

   (a)  Angle ABC = 125°.  
        Write down the size of angle ADC.  
        (a)  Angle ADC = …………..°  [1]  

   (b)  AP is the same length as PB.  
        Work out the size of angle BCD.  
        You must show your working.  
        (b)  Angle BCD = …………..°  [4]

question-components.a: Angle ABC = 125°. Write down the size of angle ADC.
question-components.b: AP is the same length as PB. Work out the size of angle BCD. You must show your working.

question-components.a: Explain why 21 is not a term in this sequence.
question-components.b.i: Find one rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.
question-components.b.ii: Find a second rule for continuing the sequence and give the next two terms.

9.question:
9  Three friends, Ann (A), Bob (B) and Carol (C), go on holiday together.

(a) They book a row of three seats on the plane.  
    When they arrive at the plane they sit in a random order.

    (i) List all the different orders they could sit on the three seats.  
        The first one has been done for you.  

          Seat 1   Seat 2   Seat 3  
          A        B        C  

        [2]

    (ii) What is the probability that Ann and Carol sit next to each other?  
         (a)(ii) ……………………………………… [1]

    (iii) What is the probability that Bob sits in seat 1 with Ann next to him?  
          (iii) …………………………………… [1]

(b) Ann, Bob and Carol have a total budget of £500 to rent a holiday apartment.  
    The apartment normally costs £50 per night, but they can get a 20% discount  
    if they book early.  

    Calculate how many extra nights they can stay in the apartment if they book early.  
    You must show your working.  

    (b) …………………………… nights  [4]

question-components.a.i: List all the different orders they could sit on the three seats.
question-components.a.ii: What is the probability that Ann and Carol sit next to each other?
question-components.a.iii: What is the probability that Bob sits in seat 1 with Ann next to him?
question-components.b: Calculate how many extra nights they can stay in the apartment if they book early.

12.question:
12  Shinya’s internet service provider gives him a graph of his internet usage in the first part of February:

  
  (The vertical axis is labeled “Internet usage (Gigabytes downloaded)” from 0 to 14.  
   The horizontal axis is labeled “Days in February” from 0 to 15.  
   A line connects plotted points corresponding to Shinya’s usage each day.)

State two reasons why this graph is misleading.

1  …………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………

2  …………………………………………………………………………………………………………………………

[2]
12.question-components: State two reasons why this graph is misleading.

13.question:
13 (a) Mia cycled 23 km, correct to the nearest km.  
What is the least distance Mia could have cycled?

(a) ………………………………………… km [1]

(b) A number x, rounded to one decimal place, is 4.7.  
   So the error interval for x is given by 4.65 ≤ x < 4.75.

   (i) A number y, rounded to two decimal places, is 4.13.  
       Write down the error interval for y.

   (b)(i) ………………………………………… [2]

   (ii) A number z, rounded to two significant figures, is 4700.  
        Write down the error interval for z.

   (b)(ii) ……………………………………… [2]

question-components.a: What is the least distance Mia could have cycled?
question-components.b.i: A number y, rounded to two decimal places, is 4.13. Write down the error interval for y.
question-components.b.ii: A number z, rounded to two significant figures, is 4700. Write down the error interval for z.

14.question:
14  This frequency diagram summarises the number of minutes Astrid’s train was late over the last 50 days:

(Frequency on the vertical axis from 0 to 20, Minutes late on the horizontal axis from 1 to 4)

(a) Use information from this diagram to estimate the probability that her train will be 4 minutes late tomorrow.  
(a) ……………………………………………………………………………………………………… [2]

(b) Explain whether your answer to part (a) gives a reliable probability.  
……………………………………………………………………………………………………………  
……………………………………………………………………………………………………… [1]

question-components.a: Use information from this diagram to estimate the probability that her train will be 4 minutes late tomorrow.
question-components.b: Explain whether your answer to part (a) gives a reliable probability.

15.question:
15  In the diagram below, AE and BD are straight lines. Both ∠B and ∠D are right angles.

   A
   |\
   | \
   |  \
   B---C---D
           \
            E
         (Not to scale)

(a) Show that triangles ABC and EDC are similar.  
     
(b) The length DE is 3.5 m.  
      The ratio BC : CD = 3 : 1.  
      Find the length AB.

question-components.a: Show that triangles ABC and EDC are similar.
question-components.b: The length DE is 3.5 m. The ratio BC : CD = 3 : 1. Find the length AB.

16.question:
16) Leo is using these numbers to make a new number:

• 11  
• 1  
• 3  
• 6  

He can use brackets, +, −, ×, and ÷ as often as he wishes.  
He cannot use any number more than once.  
He cannot use powers.  
He cannot put numbers together (for example, 136 is not allowed).  

What is the biggest number he can make?  
Show how he can make this number.
16.question-components: What is the biggest number he can make? Show how he can make this number.

17.question:
17) 180 g of copper is mixed with 105 g of zinc to make an alloy.  
The density of copper is 9 g/cm³.  
The density of zinc is 7 g/cm³.  

(a) Work out the volume of copper used in the alloy.  
(a) …………………………………… cm³ [2]  

(b) What is the density of the alloy?  
(b) …………………………………… g/cm³ [4]

question-components.a: Work out the volume of copper used in the alloy.
question-components.b: What is the density of the alloy?

18.question:
18 (a)  
(i) Solve the inequality:  
   5x + 1 > x + 13  
   [3]  

(ii) Write down the largest integer that satisfies:  
   5x – 1 < 10  
   [1]  

(b) Solve the equation:  
   3x² = 75  
   [2]  

(c) Solve the simultaneous equations:  
   4x + 3y = 5  
   2x + 3y = 1  
   [3]

question-components.a.ii: Write down the largest integer that satisfies: 5x – 1 < 10

19.question:
19  Here are the interest rates for two accounts:

Account A  
• Interest: 3% per year compound interest.  
• No withdrawals until the end of three years.  

Account B  
• Interest: 4% for the first year, 3% for the second year and 2% for the third year.  
• Withdrawals allowed at any time.  

Derrick has £10 000 he wants to invest.

(a) Calculate which account would give him the most money if he invests his money for 3 years.  
Give the difference in the interest to the nearest penny.  
You must show your working.

(a) Account ………………… by ……………… p  [5]

(b) Explain why he might not want to use Account A.

…............................................................................................................................  
…............................................................................................................................  [1]

question-components.a:
Calculate which account would give him the most money if he invests his money for 3 years. Give the difference in the interest to the nearest penny. You must show your working.

Account ………………… by ……………… p  [5]
question-components.b: Explain why he might not want to use Account A.
